quizzes.question: Fill in the blank to specify a 2-second delay before the animation begins.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Animation Properties[/h1]

[b][/b]The [b]animation-timing-function[/b] specifies the speed curve of an animation. It can have the following values:
[b]ease [/b]- specifies an animation with a slow start, then fast, then end slowly (this is default)
[b]linear [/b]- specifies an animation with the same speed from start to end
[b]ease-in[/b] - specifies an animation with a slow start
[b]ease-out[/b] - specifies an animation with a slow end
[b]ease-in-out[/b] - specifies an animation with a slow start and end
[b]cubic-bezier(n,n,n,n)[/b] - lets you define your own values in a cubic-bezier function

The CSS syntax looks like this: [code format="css" codeId="637"]animation-timing-function: linear;[/code]
[b]animation-delay[/b] - defines the delay before an animation starts. The CSS syntax looks like this: [code format="css" codeId="632"]animation-delay: 2s;[/code]
[note]The animation-delay and animation-duration values can be defined in [b]seconds (s)[/b] or [b]milliseconds (ms)[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: Which property value is used to have the animation repeat forever?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]More Animation Properties[/h1]

The [b]animation-iteration-count[/b] property determines the number of times an animation repeats. 
For example, you can set the animation to run [b]5 times:[/b][code format="css" codeId="633"]animation-iteration-count: 5;[/code]
To make the animation repeat [b]forever[/b], just use the [b]infinite[/b] value: [code format="css" codeId="634"]animation-iteration-count: [b]infinite[/b];[/code]
The [b]animation-direction[/b] indicates how the keyframe should be applied.
The values can be set as:
[b]normal [/b]- the default value, which means it plays forward from 0 % to 100%. 
[b]reverse[/b] - plays the keyframe in an opposite direction from 100 % to 0%
[b]alternate[/b] -  the animation first runs forward, then backward, then forward.
[b]alternate reverse[/b] - the animation first runs backward, then forward, then backward.
[note]If you use 0 or a negative number for the [b]animation-iteration-count[/b], the animation will never start. [/note]
